title: ISO 9241 Usability Quest
overview: You will investigate a collaborative analytics platform that struggles with discoverability and inconsistent feedback loops. Each lab moves from observation to remediation and finally to validation so that students internalize ISO 9241 clauses by using them in context.

labs.title: Lab A · Discovery Workshop
labs.summary: Frame the problem space, observe the experience, and prioritize actions grounded in ISO 9241-110 and ISO 9241-112.

labs.title: Lab B · Interaction Audit
labs.summary: Storyboard a higher fidelity flow that respects ISO guidance on presentation, control, and feedback.

labs.title: Lab C · Validation Sprint
labs.summary: Stress-test the prototype against ISO 9241-210 activities and define a lean validation plan informed by ISO 9241-11 metrics.

resources: ISO 9241-11:2018 effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction metrics
completionMessage: Debrief the team, highlight the strongest artefacts, and schedule the follow-up validation session.

challenges.title: Baseline Observation
challenges.narrative: The analytics dashboard for distributed teams has ballooned with widgets, snackbars, and legacy charts. Newcomers report fatigue and consistently miss the KPIs they need during onboarding week.
objectives: Apply ISO 9241-110 principles (self-descriptiveness, controllability, conformity with user expectations) when inspecting screens.
Collect evidence of problematic patterns that the class can discuss with the instructor.
Differentiate between subjective opinions and observations grounded in the standard.

tasks.content: Review the dashboard recording transcripts (overview cards, alerts drawer, comparison canvas) and capture gut reactions in one sentence per section.
tasks.helper: First pass = raw impressions; second pass = note every time the transcript mentions hesitation or rework.
resources: Reminder: onboarding cohorts in APAC and LATAM complained about fatigue after day 3.

tasks.instruction: Print or open the dashboard screenshot and annotate every confusing region. Next to each sticky, cite the ISO 9241-110 clause being violated and describe the consequence in plain language.
tasks.example: Alerts drawer — clause 5.3 (conformity). Critical alerts hide behind a neutral bell, so analysts expect non-urgent updates.
tasks.helper: Aim for at least eight annotations so you capture both obvious blockers and subtle friction.
checklist: Circle the UI element and label it A, B, C…
Write the violated principle under the label
Add one sentence describing user confusion
Mark severity (H/M/L) so classmates can debate later

tasks.instruction: Open ISO 9241-110 clause 5.2 (self-descriptiveness) and highlight the sentences about feedback cues before finalizing your notes.

resources.label: Plain-language summary
resources.note: Use as inspiration for conformity language.

tasks.helper: If you cannot access the PDF, ask any teammate who already downloaded the excerpt to screenshare.

tasks.instruction: Interview the instructor role-playing the product owner to list three daily tasks and two weekly tasks the dashboard must support.
tasks.example: Daily: monitor live alerts for Asia. Weekly: prep executive snapshot.
tasks.helper: Listen for verbs the PO uses (monitor, escalate, compare) and reuse them in your findings to stay contextual.

tasks.instruction: Write five observation statements that include screen area, violated principle, observed impact, and severity.
tasks.example: Trend comparison panel — self-descriptiveness — analysts misread grey trend as inactive, delaying reactions (Severity: High).
checklist: Sentence 1: name the component
Sentence 2: cite the ISO clause and quote the keyword you relied on
Sentence 3: explain the business or human impact
Sentence 4: tag severity so prioritization is easier

quizzes.question: The overview cards use identical labels and icons for different metrics. Which ISO 9241-110 principle is most clearly violated?
quizzes.rationale: Repeated icons and labels reduce the ability to understand the function without additional explanation.

quizzes.question: Students notice that critical alerts appear behind a collapsed drawer. Which principle justifies escalating this issue first?
quizzes.rationale: Critical alerts are task-relevant; hiding them undermines suitability for the primary task.

challenges.nextStepCue: Once the debrief wraps up, continue to Challenge 2 so the cohort can prioritize fixes.

challenges.title: Prioritize the Fixes
challenges.narrative: Stakeholders can only fund two tangible improvements in the next sprint, so you must argue for the most impactful corrections using ISO language.
objectives: Translate observations into remediation ideas that cite ISO 9241-110 or ISO 9241-112 clauses.
Practice impact-versus-effort reasoning while referencing evidence gathered earlier.
Draft a compliance statement the instructor can role-play as the Product Owner.

tasks.content: Spend ten minutes revisiting the observation wall. Group stickies by principle or symptom so themes emerge before prioritizing.
tasks.example: Cluster A: self-descriptiveness issues in cards. Cluster B: suitability for task issues in alert drawer.
tasks.helper: If you are remote, recreate clusters in Miro or FigJam and take a screenshot for reference.

tasks.instruction: Populate a 2x2 matrix (impact vs. effort). Inside each quadrant, list remediation ideas and cite the ISO clause backing the change.
checklist: Draw the axes: Impact (low→high) vs Effort (low→high)
Place each idea where it belongs
Write the clause (e.g., 5.3) and a 5-word rationale
Circle the two ideas you would actually ship

tasks.instruction: Search for dashboard or data-visualization pattern libraries (Atlassian, Nielsen Norman, Salesforce Lightning) and capture one example that supports each winning idea.
tasks.helper: Screenshot + one sentence is enough; focus on how the pattern reinforces your ISO argument.

tasks.instruction: Read ISO 9241-112 clause 6 (organization of information). Highlight phrases that justify how you will reorder KPIs or alerts.
tasks.helper: Pay attention to guidance on grouping by task frequency; you will quote it in your compliance note.

tasks.instruction: Write a 120-word compliance statement addressed to the Product Owner explaining which two improvements ship next sprint and why they satisfy ISO 9241-110/112.
tasks.example: Decision 1: Pin critical KPIs (clause 5.3) so analysts control focus. Decision 2: Restructure alert drawer per ISO 9241-112 grouping guidance…
checklist: Sentence 1: situation recap
Sentences 2-3: improvement #1 + clause
Sentences 4-5: improvement #2 + clause
Sentence 6: expected impact + invite for review

quizzes.question: Which remediation best aligns with ISO 9241-110 controllability?
choices: Automatically cycling through widgets every 5 seconds
Allowing users to pin two KPIs and collapse the rest
Adding color-coded gradients to every tile
Removing confirmation dialogs to speed up review
quizzes.rationale: Pinned KPIs hand control back to the analyst without forcing unwanted automation.

quizzes.question: When defending the alert redesign, which ISO 9241-112 concept strengthens your case?
quizzes.rationale: Grouping alerts by severity and proximity improves information organization and comprehension.

challenges.nextStepCue: After the prioritization board feels solid, head into Lab B to keep momentum.

challenges.title: Interaction Storyboard
challenges.narrative: The most critical task is assembling a weekly report in under five minutes. The flow currently includes redundant confirm dialogs and delayed feedback, so you will storyboard a better experience.
objectives: Sequence the workflow into 6–8 frames with clear triggers, system responses, and sensory cues.
Apply ISO 9241-112 guidance on information presentation to reduce cognitive load.
Align feedback timing and modality with ISO 9241-143 recommendations.

tasks.content: Study the instructor's annotated flow. Pay special attention to the sticky notes placed at data selection, confirmation, and export—they indicate where people currently stall.
tasks.helper: Write the timestamp of each friction point so you can reference it quickly when pitching the new storyboard.

tasks.instruction: Read ISO 9241-112 clause 7 (emphasizing important information). Underline phrases about ordering, proximity, and highlighting before you sketch frame 1.
tasks.helper: Translate at least one clause sentence into your own words and write it at the top of your storyboard for quick reference.

tasks.instruction: Create 6–8 storyboard frames. For each frame, capture: user intent, UI surface, input method, system response, and immediate feedback cue.
tasks.example: Frame 3 — Intent: choose dataset. Surface: modal. Input: multi-select list. System response: preview chips update. Feedback: inline confirmation banner.
checklist: Frame title = verb + object (e.g., Select dataset)
Add arrows showing what triggers the next frame
Color-code frames where the system gives feedback
Note any ISO principle you deliberately applied

tasks.instruction: Ask subject-matter experts (played by the instructor) how they double-check exported PDFs today. Capture verbatim quotes about frustrations or hacks.
tasks.helper: Prompt them with scenarios: 'When was the last time you caught an error too late?' so you collect actionable stories.

tasks.instruction: Highlight two storyboard moments where proactive feedback prevents errors (inline validation, progress indicator, preview, etc.). Explain why each aligns with ISO 9241-143 timing guidance.
tasks.example: Moment 1: inline validation warns about missing filters before export, referencing ISO 9241-143 clause on immediate feedback.
checklist: State the frame number
Describe the feedback modality
Link to the ISO clause
Describe the risk it mitigates

quizzes.question: Where should an inline confirmation appear to respect ISO 9241-143 feedback timing?
choices: Immediately after the user selects the dataset
Only if the user requests help
quizzes.rationale: Immediate feedback after selection ensures the user knows the system captured the correct dataset.

quizzes.question: Which adjustment lowers cognitive load according to ISO 9241-112?
choices: Grouping related filters and naming them with verbs
quizzes.rationale: Grouping and action-oriented labels improve the organization dimension of information presentation.

challenges.nextStepCue: When your storyboard pitch is done, transition to validation thinking in Lab C.

challenges.title: Guideline Compliance Test
challenges.narrative: A clickable prototype now demonstrates the notification settings micro-interaction. Your job is to verify it against ISO 9241-210 activities, ensuring the design remains human-centred.
objectives: Map each interaction to the ISO 9241-210 activity it satisfies (understand context, specify requirements, produce design solutions, evaluate designs).
Define measurable acceptance criteria the class can use during critiques.
Connect metrics back to ISO 9241-11 dimensions of effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction.

tasks.content: Review the notification prototype walkthrough notes twice. On the second pass, flag every toggle change or preview update with a timestamp.
tasks.helper: Capture timestamps (mm:ss) for each interaction; you will reference them when judging if evaluation steps exist.

tasks.instruction: Complete the ISO 9241-210 activity checklist: mark Evidence Present, Missing, or Needs Follow-up for each activity (understand context, specify requirements, produce solutions, evaluate designs).
checklist: Row 1: Understand context — what artefact proves it?
Row 2: Specify requirements — do we see measurable criteria?
Row 3: Produce solutions — list prototypes or design decisions
Row 4: Evaluate designs — note tests, KPIs, or peer reviews

tasks.instruction: Consult ISO 9241-11 clause 4 and note exact wording for effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction. Translate them into friendly definitions you can hand to stakeholders.
tasks.helper: Write three bullet points like 'Efficiency = time + resources' and keep them visible as you draft KPIs.

tasks.instruction: Ask the instructor (acting as PM) about constraints: maximum time allowed to configure notifications, acceptable error rate, and tooling limits.
tasks.example: PM says setup must stay under 90 seconds with zero critical errors.
tasks.helper: Capture constraints verbatim so you can turn them directly into acceptance criteria.

tasks.instruction: Draft three acceptance criteria. Each must include metric, benchmark, measurement method, and linked ISO dimension (effectiveness, efficiency, satisfaction).
tasks.example: Efficiency — 'Average setup time ≤ 90s measured via moderated test'.
checklist: Criterion title
ISO dimension + clause reference
Metric + how you capture it
Benchmark and rationale

quizzes.question: Evaluating whether the toggle states communicate status belongs to which ISO 9241-210 activity?
choices: Understand and specify context of use
quizzes.rationale: You are checking a solution versus requirements, so it is the evaluation activity.

quizzes.question: Which KPI best reflects efficiency for this micro-interaction?
choices: Percentage of users who prefer dark mode
Average time to configure notifications without errors
quizzes.rationale: Efficiency relates to resource expenditure, so time to configure without errors is appropriate.

challenges.nextStepCue: Once KPIs are peer-reviewed, unlock the final field validation brief.

challenges.title: Field Validation Brief
challenges.narrative: Leadership needs a lean remote validation plan before releasing the new dashboard experience. Resources are scarce, but evidence must tie back to ISO 9241-11.
objectives: Design a validation protocol that balances effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction measures.
State assumptions, participant profiles, and logistical constraints in a concise brief.
Prepare talking points the instructor can use while role-playing executive stakeholders.

tasks.content: You can recruit four remote analysts (two power users, two newcomers). Each session is 60 minutes on MS Teams with screen-share and recording enabled if consented.
tasks.helper: List the analysts' time zones to confirm you can schedule within one week.

tasks.instruction: Read ISO 9241-11 clause 5 and note what constitutes effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction. Use those definitions to decide which metrics truly matter.

resources.label: UX metrics crib sheet
resources.note: Map each suggested metric to ISO dimensions.

tasks.helper: Translate each dimension into a question you will ask participants (e.g., 'How confident did you feel finishing the alert setup?').

tasks.instruction: Outline the study flow: warm-up rapport, scenario briefing, task execution with think-aloud, metric capture, reflective debrief, wrap-up. Assign an approximate time budget to every segment.
checklist: Warm-up (5 min): context + consent
Scenario walkthrough (5 min): align expectations
Task block (35 min): 3 sub tasks + probes
Metrics pass (10 min): SUS + tailored Likert
Wrap-up (5 min): recap + next steps
tasks.helper: Color-code the parts where you collect quantitative vs qualitative data so you never skip a measurement.

tasks.instruction: Ask the instructor/legal proxy about privacy requirements: storage duration for recordings, anonymization expectations, and whether NDAs are needed.
tasks.example: Legal requirement: delete raw recordings after 30 days and mask client names in notes.
tasks.helper: Document any mandatory disclosures—you will use them in participant invitations.

tasks.instruction: Write a one-page validation brief listing: participants, context-of-use assumptions, tasks, metrics, risk mitigations, and go/no-go criteria tied to ISO 9241-11 thresholds.
tasks.example: Go/no-go: ship only if 3/4 participants finish under 4 minutes AND SUS ≥ 80.
checklist: Header with purpose and date
Table with participant archetypes
Task list aligned to ISO dimensions
Metrics + target values
Risks + mitigations
Decision rule

quizzes.question: Which metric most directly covers satisfaction per ISO 9241-11?
quizzes.rationale: SUS captures perceived satisfaction and is an established post-task measure.

quizzes.question: What is the minimum detail you must capture when describing participants?
choices: Role, expertise with analytics tools, and location
quizzes.rationale: ISO 9241-11 stresses understanding the user group, which includes role, experience, and environment.

challenges.nextStepCue: Reveal the collective score and facilitate a retrospective using the brief.
